2.56.text:
The Possession (2012)
This 2012 horror film is based on the haunted

8.63.text:
In real life, the infamous dybbuk box was
a wine cabinet which was allegedly haunted

17.15.text:
Legend has it that the box belonged to Havela,
a Holocaust survivor who had bought it prior

25.06.text:
Kevin Mannis, who wrote a story about the
incident, had bought the box from Havela’s

32.80.text:
Learning that it was a family heirloom, he
wanted to return the box, but Havela’s granddaughter

37.85.text:
said, “We don’t want it,” adding that
a dybbuk haunted it.

43.00.text:
Inside the box, Mannis discovered an odd array
of items: two pennies from the 1920s, a wine

49.29.text:
goblet made of gold, a candle holder with
four stems shaped like octopus legs, a single

55.86.text:
dried rosebud, a tiny statue with the word
“Shalom” engraved in it, and two locks

62.15.text:
of hair – one blonde, one black – each
bound separately with cords.

69.26.text:
The box has been owned by a number of individuals,
and all have reported strange happenings occurring

76.76.text:
Many have said that a strong smell of jasmine
flowers and cat urine emanate from the box,

81.88.text: as well as nightmares that entail an old hag.

85.12.text:
Mannis, himself, reported that when people
would stay with him while he owned the box,

89.63.text:
several of his visitors shared the same nightmares
and, when he passed it off to his mother as

94.07.text: a birthday gift, she suffered a stroke.

97.81.text:
Other owners have claimed that they suffered
health problems once they came into possession

101.71.text:
of the cursed box, including welts, coughing
up blood, hair falling out, and hives.

108.53.text:
The last known owner bought the box off of
eBay and, after speaking with Rabbis about

113.78.text:
how to seal the evil spirit inside the box,
he did so and hid the dybbuk in an unmarked

120.61.text:
The film follows a similar plot, where a girl
called Em finds a strange wooden box, engraved

126.37.text: with Hebrew, at a yard sale.

129.17.text:
Her father, Clyde, buys the box for her, and
she starts to hear whispers coming from inside.

135.59.text:
Opening it, she discovers several odd items,
including a dead moth and a ring.

140.93.text:
Once she starts wearing the ring, she begins
acting strangely and violently, and odd things

147.60.text: start to happen inside their home.

150.43.text:
The dybbuk eventually possesses not just Em,
but Clyde too.

156.11.text:
Exorcisms are performed, but once the box
is gotten rid of, it is still cursed, claiming

181.89.text:
Eaten Alive (1980)
Based on a real-life psychopath, Eaten Alive

186.37.text:
is inspired by crazy man, Joe Ball, an American
serial killer who may have fed up to twenty

195.46.text:
Ball served in the front lines in World War
I before beginning his bootlegging career.

201.75.text:
Once Prohibition had ended, he continued his
career in liquor by opening a saloon in Elmendorf,

208.69.text: The Sociable Inn held a pond with six alligators.

212.98.text:
He charged extra from his customers to view
the monsters during their feeding time.

217.21.text:
He allegedly fed the alligators mainly cats
and dogs.

220.73.text:
It didn’t take long for Ball to start murdering
area women and adding them to alligators’

227.52.text: Barmaids, ex-girlfriends, and even his wife.

231.43.text:
When the last went missing in 1938, sheriff’s
deputies came to interrogate him.

236.78.text:
Apparently, Ball knew the jig was up and didn’t
want to rot in prison, so he shot himself

243.59.text:
with a handgun he’d stashed away in the
saloon’s cash register.

248.41.text:
Clifford Wheeler, Ball’s handyman, led officers
to the decomposing bodies of two of the victims,

257.40.text:
Clifford had helped Ball try to dispose of
them.

260.47.text:
Wheeler claimed that Ball had killed twenty
or more women, all of whom he’d fed to the

266.70.text:
“The Alligator Man” is now a thing of
Texas folklore.

271.41.text:
Makes you wonder what else lurks in them there
swamps.

276.72.text:
The Rite (2011)
Yet another exorcism movie, The Rite is based

280.68.text:
on the life of one of America’s most famous
exorcists, Father Gary Thomas.

286.87.text:
The thriller follows experiences Thomas had
when he was being trained as an exorcist.

292.54.text:
In the film, the son of a funeral home owner,
Michael Kovak, hopes to earn a free college

297.70.text:
degree by entering a seminary school and renouncing
his vows once he’s received his diploma.

304.26.text:
After Michael is ordained as deacon, he resigns,
claiming his faith is lacking.

309.56.text:
However, a chain of events leads Michael,
still dressed in his clerical clothes, to

315.01.text:
give out the last rites to a fatally injured
cyclist on the street.

319.76.text:
Upon absolving the girl of her sins, Michael
returns to the church after Father Matthew

324.27.text: convinces him to become an exorcist.

326.47.text:
He didn’t take much convincing, being that
he was told that a resignation might lead

331.34.text:
to the Church turning his scholarship into
a $100,000 student loan.

336.59.text:
He is then sent to the Vatican for exorcism
classes with Father Xavier.

341.85.text:
Michael soon finds himself alongside another
senior exorcist, Father Lucas, in the home

346.85.text:
of a pregnant young girl named Rosaria, who
was raped by her father, resulting in her

354.15.text:
The possession causes the girl to speak fluent
English and cough up three nails.

359.79.text:
Eventually, Rosaria tries to drown herself
and, while hospitalized, Father Lucas performs

369.08.text:
However, that night, Rosaria dies from blood
loss after a miscarriage.

373.91.text:
It seems that the evil didn’t go far; Father
Lucas begins showing signs of demonic possession.

380.56.text:
He, himself, knows that he is possessed, and
asks Michael to find Father Xavier to perform

388.63.text:
Unable to contact him, Michael successfully
performs the exorcism, himself.

393.75.text:
This experience returns Michael’s lost faith
to him, and he stays with the priesthood.

399.21.text:
All of this, based upon the real-life experiences
of Father Gary Thomas.

406.90.text:
The Zodiac Killer (1971)
Most people have heard of the Zodiac Killer.

411.82.text:
This infamous serial killer committed the
murders of three men and four women in San

416.26.text:
Francisco from December of 1968 to October
of 1969.

422.66.text:
The 1971 film is loosely based on these events,
though it names the killer, provides him a

433.57.text:
In the film, the Zodiac Killer is a postal
carrier.

437.45.text:
His friend is falsely named the Zodiac Killer
after a series of events leads him to claim

442.88.text:
to be the murderer, and he is shot dead by
police.

447.49.text:
This is when the real Zodiac Killer starts
taunting the police and adding to his body

452.27.text:
count by killing several random people, as
well as people he knows who start to mock

458.11.text: his alter-ego or are not nice to him, personally.

462.86.text:
The film creates a motive for his crime spree
through the man’s unhappy relationship with

468.97.text:
The real-life Zodiac Killer is a mystery to
this day.

472.49.text:
His attacks included gunning down two high
school lovers on their first date, shooting

477.56.text:
another couple near the site of the first
murder (although the man survived the shooting),

482.88.text:
stabbing another couple (again, the male victim
survived), and shooting a cabbie dead.

489.83.text:
Several more attacks have been attributed
to the Zodiac Killer, including the kidnapping

493.75.text:
of a pregnant woman and her child (they managed
to escape) and the stabbing of a young woman

498.87.text: who was studying in the library.

501.08.text:
As depicted in the film, the Zodiac Killer
truly did taunt the police, sending letters

506.05.text:
that termed himself the ‘Zodiac,’ along
with four cryptograms, only one of which has

512.62.text:
The solved cipher reads: “I LIKE KILLING
PEOPLE BECAUSE IT IS SO MUCH FUN IT IS MORE

519.04.text:
FUN THAN KILLING WILD GAME IN THE FORREST
BECAUSE MAN IS THE MOST DANGEROUE ANAMAL OF

524.23.text:
ALL TO KILL SOMETHING GIVES ME THE MOST THRILLING
EXPERENCE IT IS EVEN BETTER THAN GETTING YOUR

530.82.text:
ROCKS OFF WITH A GIRL THE BEST PART OF IT
IS THAE WHEN I DIE I WILL BE REBORN IN PARADICE

538.34.text:
AND THEI HAVE KILLED WILL BECOME MY SLAVES
I WILL NOT GIVE YOU MY NAME BECAUSE YOU WILL

543.37.text:
TRY TO SLOI DOWN OR ATOP MY COLLECTIOG OF
SLAVES FOR MY AFTERLIFE EBEORIETEMETHHPITI.”

550.99.text:
Some believed that the killer must have been
involved in law enforcement at some point,

555.15.text:
because there was an utter lack of evidence
each time he killed.

558.70.text:
Although suspects were named, the evidence
was never conclusive for a conviction.

563.70.text:
The high-profile unsolved case was eventually
closed, but as new technologies began to advance,

572.36.text: However, no new leads were drawn.

576.55.text:
The Exorcism of Emily Rose (2005)
The Exorcism of Emily Rose is based on a series

582.34.text:
of real-life exorcisms performed on a young
German woman, Anneliese Michel, which eventually

590.25.text:
Anneliese had an epileptic seizure at 16 and
was diagnosed with temporal lobe epilepsy.

596.53.text:
She also suffered from depression and was
sent to a psychiatric hospital for treatment.

601.76.text:
This is where she started hearing voices and
couldn’t stand to be around religious objects,

608.24.text:
By the age of twenty, she claimed she saw
“devil faces” and began having other spiritual

613.48.text:
delusions, including hallucinating voices
that would tell her to “rot in hell” and

618.39.text: condemn her while she was praying.

620.30.text:
Soon, she became suicidal and, believing demons
possessed their daughter, Michel’s parents

626.01.text: sought help from a Catholic priest.

627.85.text:
At first, the priests refused, citing the
need for a bishop’s permission to perform

634.23.text:
But Michel’s condition worsened; she became
more aggressive, started to eat insects, drank

640.98.text: her own urine, and injured herself.

644.61.text:
In the end, two local priests sought permission
from the bishop and, over a ten-month period,

649.92.text:
they performed exorcism rites on the young
woman.

652.99.text:
Priest Arnold Renz performed the first exorcism
in 1975, after which Michel’s parents ceased

659.70.text:
any and all medical treatment, relying solely
on the exorcism to improve her condition.

665.32.text:
67 sessions were performed, some lasting up
to four hours.

670.34.text:
Michel didn’t improve, saying her condition
was a sacrifice, and claiming she was “dying

676.81.text:
to atone for the wayward youth of the day
and the apostate priests of the modern church.”

682.48.text:
As she weakened, she refused to eat or drink
and, on the 1st of July, 1976, she died from

689.66.text:
dehydration and malnutrition, weighing 68
pounds on her deathbed.

695.66.text:
Her autopsy showed that she had broken knees,
resulting from her rigorous genuflections,

700.78.text:
she’d contracted pneumonia, and she’d
been in a state of semi-starvation for the

710.03.text:
The rarely used 400-year-old rites of exorcism
caught the eye of the media and the public

731.81.text:
The Catholic Church had all but done away
with exorcisms since the 18th century.

736.05.text:
The priests involved were found guilty of
negligent homicide, as were Michel’s parents.

741.69.text:
They served a three-year probation sentence
and paid a fine, but the case was highly charged

746.99.text:
as negligence and abuse, while also bringing
religious hysteria and mental disorder to

754.34.text:
The Strangers (2008)
The Strangers is a combination of real-life

758.61.text:
events and inspiration from the serial killer,
Charles Manson.

763.08.text:
The director of the film, Bryan Bertino, drew
from his own childhood.

768.29.text:
One night a stranger knocked at his door,
asked if someone was home, and then walked

772.79.text:
away when he was told that this person didn’t
live there.

776.10.text:
But Bertino later discovered that someone
had broken into a number of homes in the neighborhood

783.80.text:
In it, at 4 in the morning, a stranger knocks
at the door of a summer home where a couple

790.89.text:
The woman asks for someone who isn’t there
and then leaves.

794.65.text:
James, the man in the coupling, heads out
for a bit, and the woman, Kristen, hears odd

802.49.text:
She finds a man in a sack mask watching her
from the backyard, and she hides from him

810.28.text:
Kristen tells James what happened, after which
he finds his car has been burglarized and

815.16.text:
the woman who had knocked earlier is watching
him from a distance, wearing a doll mask.

820.58.text:
Through a series of events, James and Kristen
eventually find themselves captured by the

824.87.text:
masked strangers, tied to chairs in their
living room.

832.62.text: The woman responds, “Because you were home.”

836.57.text:
The couple is then stabbed repeatedly by the
strangers, and the movie ends with two young

843.49.text:
Bertino, the film’s director, cites Helter
Skelter, a true crime book about the Manson

849.52.text: Family murders, as a primary source of inspiration.

854.74.text:
Manson is known to have led a sort of cult
commune in California in the late ‘60s,

859.48.text:
in which he preached “Helter Skelter,”
a term taken from a song by the Beatles.

865.64.text:
Manson thought it meant an apocalyptic race
war was approaching, and he thought murdering

870.14.text: people would help begin that war.

873.26.text:
In the summer of ’69, the Manson Family
murdered nine people, according to Charles

882.87.text:
The Haunting In Connecticut (2009)
Loosely based on real events that took place,

888.12.text:
this 2009 American psychological horror film
is said to be about Carmen Snedeker and her

893.18.text:
family who lived in Southington, Connecticut
in 1986.

898.64.text:
Famed paranormal investigators, Ed and Lorraine
Warren, said that the Snedeker home served

905.75.text:
The morticians who worked there, the Warrens
claimed, had committed necrophilia with the

912.06.text:
An exorcism was performed in order to rid
of the strong supernatural forces that had

918.69.text:
Catholic exorcists were brought in to perform
the exorcism.

921.91.text:
A wax effigy of the Virgin Mary used in the
exorcism is now on display in Zaffis’ Museum

928.40.text: The statue was disfigured during the rites.

933.26.text:
In the film, a similar supernatural force
haunts the house of the Campbells’.

938.58.text:
The Campbells had rented out a home that was
closer to the hospital, as one of the film’s

947.08.text:
Matt moves into the basement and finds a strange
door there.

951.17.text:
He soon starts to have creepy visions, involving
corpses and a bearded man.

956.91.text:
Peter discovers that the house used to be
a funeral home, and the strange door was the

963.54.text:
Matt’s visions begin to become more traumatic,
and his behavior strange.

968.71.text:
At one point, the family finds he’s scratched
at a wall until his fingers are bloody.

974.54.text:
The family starts to dig into the strange
visions and behavior.

977.46.text:
They discover that a man called Ramsey Aickman
used to run the funeral home and would conduct

983.15.text:
séances with a young man named Jonah, who
Matt had envisioned.

987.12.text:
One of the séances led to multiple deaths,
including that of Aickman, after which Jonah

994.08.text:
Though many believe Jonah’s spirit to be
the evil one, in the end, it turns out that

998.07.text:
Jonah was actually protecting them from the
evil spirits – corpses that Aickman had

1002.83.text: hid in the walls of the house.

1005.68.text:
Jonah had been cremated alive by them during
the séance.

1009.56.text:
When the family discovers this, they remove
the corpses from the walls and Matt lights

1013.94.text: them and the room on fire.

1016.11.text: Luckily, Matt survives the fire and his cancer.

1019.27.text:
And once the corpses are freed, the evil leaves
the house as well…although it will likely

1025.64.text: hang about you long after the movie is over.

1031.34.text:
The Girl Next Door (2007)
In 1965, a truly evil crime unfolded in the

1038.66.text:
The Girl Next Door is loosely based on this
crime.

1042.37.text:
What occurred in Indianapolis at the hands
of Gertrude Baniszewski, her children, and

1047.76.text:
some other neighborhood kids, can only be
described as torture.

1051.93.text:
For $20 per week, Baniszewski had been entrusted
to take care of a 16-year-old girl, Sylvia

1058.90.text: Likens, along with her sister, Jenny.

1061.78.text:
Sylvia’s parents were carnival workers,
and her father, Lester, boarded the two sisters

1066.65.text:
with Baniszewski when their mother was put
in jail for shoplifting.

1070.41.text:
He asked Baniszewski to “straighten his
daughters out.”

1075.15.text:
Baniszewski “straightened them out” by
beating them with paddles when she felt stressed

1081.80.text:
For some reason, she began zeroing in specifically
on Sylvia, emotionally and physically abusing

1087.22.text:
her and encouraging her children to do so
as well.

1091.14.text:
The older children started beating her, pushing
her down flights of stairs, and even kicking

1096.79.text:
Baniszewski called Sylvia a prostitute and
would rant about how filthy she was.

1102.44.text:
Soon, Stephanie Baniszewski’s boyfriend,
Coy Hubbard, became involved in the physical

1108.05.text: abuse, along with the pair’s peers.

1111.25.text:
They were, again, encouraged by Baniszewski
to beat and torture her, tie her up, put out

1116.54.text:
lit cigarettes on her, burn her with boiling
water, make her eat feces, put salt in her

1121.62.text: open wounds, and sexually assault her.

1125.16.text:
The Likens girls tried to contact their parents
and family members for help, but their letters

1131.21.text:
Their older sister thought they were exaggerating
and just wanted to get out of their situation.

1135.18.text:
She did, however, visit the Baniszewski home
and contacted social services when she’d

1140.89.text:
learned from Gertrude that Sylvia had supposedly
run away.

1145.09.text:
The Likens parents completely ignored their
cries for help.

1148.89.text:
Eventually, Baniszewski would not allow Likens
to go to school, locked her in the basement,

1155.32.text:
made her bath in scalding water, rubbed salt
in the burns, and deprived her of drinking

1160.31.text: water to the point that she was dehydrated.

1162.71.text:
Baniszewski took a burning hot needle and
scratched into Sylvia’s abdomen: “I’m

1167.71.text: a prostitute and proud of it.”

1171.13.text:
She then forced her to write a note to her
parents, indicating that she had run away.

1175.89.text:
Her plan was to have her children dump her
withered body in a nearby forest to die.

1181.11.text:
Sylvia tried to run away before they were
able to achieve this, but she was caught and

1186.33.text:
locked back in the basement where she was,
again, tortured and died the next day of malnutrition,

1191.78.text:
shock, and a brain hemorrhage at the age of
16.

1196.83.text:
Stephanie Baniszewski realized she was not
breathing and asked Richard Hobbs to call

1202.46.text:
Gertrude gave the police the “runaway”
letter she’d forced Sylvia to write.

1206.30.text:
She told the police that Sylvia had agreed
to prostitute herself to a group of boys,

1211.45.text: but the boys had taken her and tortured her.

1213.80.text:
However, Jenny Likens asked to speak to the
police in confidence before they left the

1219.13.text:
They found Sylvia’s body and, along with
Jenny’s statement, brought the Baniszewski

1224.02.text:
family and those neighborhood youths who were
involved in the despicable torture and murder

1231.42.text:
Gertrude and her daughter, Paula, were sentenced
to life in prison.

1235.75.text:
The neighborhood boys involved, and John Baniszewski,
were convicted of manslaughter.

1240.34.text:
The prosecutor described the case as “the
most terrible crime ever committed in the

1247.38.text:
Child's Play (1988)
Believe it or not, the infamous Chucky doll

1252.93.text: is based on a true story.

1254.45.text:
Author and painter, Robert Eugene Otto, claims
that his nurse put a voodoo curse on one of

1260.56.text:
his dolls, and the script of Child’s Play
is based on this haunted doll.

1266.01.text:
The real cursed doll, also known as Robert
the Enchanted Doll or Robert the Haunted Doll,

1271.96.text:
is at the center of ghost tours in the Key
West region.

1275.57.text:
Robert has woolen or yarn hair and is dressed
like an American sailor from the early 1900s.

1282.04.text:
Although Chucky doesn’t at all resemble
Robert, he is certainly equally as creepy.

1286.69.text:
Child’s Play is the first installment in
the series of slasher films, in which a mother

1291.51.text:
gifts her son a doll which is possessed by
the soul of a famed Chicago serial killer.

1296.97.text:
The man’s evil soul enters the doll, after
he is killed in a shootout with homicide detective,

1302.05.text: Mike Norris, in a toy shop.

1305.09.text:
When the doll is gifted to the boy, Andy,
the boy’s babysitter is killed that night.

1309.77.text:
She falls out a window after being slammed
in the face with a hammer, and Andy is suspected

1315.87.text:
The next day, he is ordered by Chucky to go
downtown, because the serial killer wants

1320.85.text:
to pay a visit to Eddie, one of the serial
killer’s “friends” who’d abandoned

1326.02.text:
The doll turns up the gas on the stove and
messes with Eddie until he takes a shot at

1332.45.text:
Andy is, again, suspected of the murder and
is put into a mental hospital.

1337.04.text:
Through a series of events, Chucky discovers
that he must escape the doll’s body and

1341.82.text:
possess the first person who was told about
him – Andy – while Mike and Andy’s mother

1346.42.text:
discover that the serial killer’s soul can
be destroyed via a fatal injury to the heart.

1352.40.text:
After a lot of violence and many false death
scenes, Mike finally shoots Chucky in the

1357.57.text: heart, killing the soul of the serial killer.

1360.12.text:
…or so we’re led to believe, until the
next installment comes out.

1367.02.text:
The Conjuring (2013)
Paranormal investigators, Ed and Lorraine

1371.58.text:
Warren, are the witnesses of the real-life
haunting that inspired The Conjuring.

1376.05.text:
In the film, the Warrens, themselves, are
represented, responding to the Perron family

1383.74.text:
The family made claims about strange and volatile
events occurring at their farmhouse, and the

1388.86.text:
real-life Warrens say the case was one of
the most difficult to address.

1392.64.text:
In the film adaptation, the Perrons move into
the farmhouse with their five daughters and

1397.30.text:
their dog, who won’t enter the home, perhaps
suspecting what horrors await the family inside.

1403.84.text:
One of the kids finds a cellar entrance that’s
boarded up and, within a few days, a series

1411.73.text:
The family dog is found dead, one of the daughters,
Christine, feels an evil spirit pulling on

1416.47.text:
her leg, and another of the girls, Carolyn,
hears strange clapping in the hall.

1422.09.text:
She follows the noises to see where they’re
coming from and ends up in the basement, where

1427.94.text:
Simultaneously, two of the other girls are
ambushed by another evil spirit living above

1434.32.text:
This is when the Warrens are called in for
their expertise.

1437.73.text:
Upon examination, the Warrens recommend an
exorcism of the farmhouse.

1442.03.text:
They must dig a little deeper to seek permission
from the Catholic Church to go ahead with

1446.44.text: What they find is deeply disturbing.

1448.89.text:
The history of the house’s former occupant
explains why evil resides here.

1452.48.text:
An alleged witch, named Bathsheba, had sacrificed
her baby to the devil.

1457.58.text: The baby had only been a week old.

1459.66.text:
She then placed a curse on her land and those
who would later reside there, after which

1465.64.text:
Ever since that day in 1863, a number of murders
and suicides had taken place on the property.

1472.17.text:
After further investigation, including installing
bells and cameras throughout the house, the

1476.72.text:
Perron family decides to stay at a hotel,
while the Warrens appeal to the Church for

1482.36.text:
But while they are waiting, it is discovered
that Carolyn has been possessed by Bathsheba

1489.86.text:
Ed Warren decides to try and perform the exorcism,
as there’s no time to wait for a priest.

1495.35.text:
He is attacked by Bathsheba during the attempted
exorcism.

1499.54.text:
While Ed is incapacitated, Carolyn tries to
kill April as well, but is distracted by Lorraine

1504.90.text:
until the exorcism has been successfully performed,

1546.92.text:

1560.87.text:

Although he was diagnosed as legally insane,

1577.54.text:
When his beloved mother died, Gein lived on

1587.40.text:

1596.98.text:

1604.91.text:

Investigators searched the rest of Gein’s

1617.28.text:

1636.15.text:
The movie took some of these ideas under consideration

1640.72.text:
who picked off characters in the movie, one

1647.78.text:
His home – also a farmhouse, like Gein’s

Although these gory real-life details are

1657.75.text:
the dramatization of cinema pales in comparison
to the gruesome nature of true events.

The Catholic Church performed an exorcism

1667.80.text:
on a 14-year-old American boy in the late

The boy’s pseudonym in records that documented

1677.16.text:
Bishop was the acting priest who alleged that
Roland was possessed by a demon.

1682.53.text:
The famous film, The Exorcist, is based on
these real-life events.

1688.20.text:
Roland didn’t have many friends as a child,
and his adult family members were those he

1694.54.text:
His Aunt Harriet particularly influenced him,

1701.24.text:
When Aunt Harriet died, it’s alleged that

1714.97.text:

1748.24.text:

1789.73.text:

The story of the Lutz family’s paranormal

1814.59.text:
experiences was first showcased in a book

1821.10.text:
After the book came out, films under the same

1827.39.text:
The Horror in question happened in 1974 in

1832.82.text:
It was then and there that Ronald DeFeo, Jr.
murdered six of his family members in their

1837.73.text: big Dutch Colonial house in Long Island.

1841.01.text:
The next year, when the Lutz family moved
into the house, they were haunted by paranormal

1845.50.text:
happenings and abandoned the dwelling after
less than a month.

1849.52.text:
Knowing that the gruesome murders had happened

1853.90.text:

1860.45.text:
Acting upon the suggestion of a friend, George

1867.76.text:
As the Lutzes unpacked, Father Mancuso splashed

1873.37.text:
This is when he heard a deep male voice command,
“Get out!”

1878.57.text:
The priest later warned the Lutzes not to
enter the room on the second floor where he’d

1884.47.text:
He also developed stigmatic blisters on his

1890.19.text:
Nothing seemed out of the ordinary to the

1897.39.text:
George woke up around 3:15AM every day, which

1904.65.text:
Kathy started to have nightmares about the

1910.83.text:
Throughout the house, there were cold spots

1914.57.text:
and perfume, and swarms of flies, even though

1920.00.text:
While all of these things could be explained

1923.92.text:

1935.15.text: half-blown out head in the fireplace.

Their five-year-old daughter, Missy, suddenly

1942.92.text:
Jodie, who she said was a piggy creature,

1953.98.text:

1967.89.text:
These are just some of the bizarre events

1972.48.text:

1980.43.text:
A Nightmare On Elm Street (2010)
This slasher film, which first premiered in

1984.89.text:
1984 and was revisited in 2010, is not so
much based on a single real person, as it

1990.94.text:
was on a group of people: Laotian refugees
who mysteriously died in their sleep in the

1997.86.text:
The New York Times reported that 18 healthy
refugees with no symptoms of disease or ill

2002.36.text:
health had suddenly died, and that there seemed
to be no foul play involved.

2007.56.text:
The strange thing was that each of the refugees
died in the same way – sleeping in their

2012.02.text: beds and crying out suddenly in terror.

2015.11.text:
Experts, at the time, diagnosed the fatalities
as “nightmare death syndrome.”

2020.14.text:
In essence, the otherwise healthy refugees
had allegedly died from fatal night terrors.

2027.32.text:
But another theory may better explain the
sudden and mysterious deaths.

2031.61.text:
After the hearts were examined by Dr. Robert
Kirschner, he found what he’d hypothesized:

2036.00.text: the 18 refugees shared a genetic defect.

2040.61.text:
The hearts of the victims were enlarged, and
the fibers that carried electronic impulses

2045.02.text:
from the brain to the heart had, essentially,
short-circuited.

2049.50.text:
This defect, along with the stress of immigrating
to a foreign country, triggered by intense

2054.39.text:
nightmares, may have caused the victims’
hearts to fail.

2058.57.text:
A Nightmare on Elm Street is somewhat inspired
by this rare series of deaths, as the villain

2063.45.text:
in the film, Freddy Krueger, murders teenagers
in their own nightmares.

2069.49.text:
Psycho (1960)
The super creepy body snatcher, Ed Gein, makes

2074.44.text:
another appearance on this list of scary movies
inspired by real people.

2079.29.text:
Not only did he inspire The Texas Chainsaw
Massacre, but his intensely creepy relationship

2083.84.text:
with his mother also inspired the intensely
creepy mother-son dynamic in the movie, Psycho.

2089.09.text:
This oldschool horror flick pits a young man,
dressed as his dead mother, against unsuspecting

2097.15.text:
To recap, Ed Gein was the mentally insane
body snatcher who bedecked his home with the

2102.02.text:
“trophies” of skin and bones that he’d
exhumed from bodies he’d stolen from cemeteries,

2106.96.text: as well as from his own victims.

2108.66.text:
But it was his disturbing relationship with
his mother that inspired Psycho.

2113.14.text:
Augusta, Ed Gein’s mother, deeply influenced
her son, preaching to her boys that women

2119.46.text:
were the devil’s instruments and that the
world was inherently evil.

2123.15.text:
She’d frequently read graphic verses from
the Bible, often those that involved murder

2130.20.text:
Her impact on Ed, in particular, frightened
his brother, Henry, to the point that he tried

2134.82.text:
to disparage their mother when she wasn’t
around, in order to tap down Ed’s affection

2140.50.text:
This may be why Henry ended up dead while
the pair burnt marsh vegetation on the property.

2145.55.text:
Although some people suspected that Ed had
murdered his brother, foul play was dismissed,

2152.64.text:
When his mother grew sick, Ed took great care
of her.

2155.63.text:
She died of a stroke in 1945, after which
Ed was alone.

2160.06.text:
This may be what led to his nocturnal visits
to the graveyard to dig up middle-aged women

2166.35.text:
From the bodies, he extracted bones and tanned
the skin to create his unsightly paraphernalia.

2172.22.text:
He even built a “woman suit” in order
to become his own mother.

2177.42.text:
This real-life killer is not a far cry from
Norman Bates, the lead in Psycho, who exhumes

2182.37.text:
his mother’s corpse and dresses up as her,
oscillating between his own persona and that

2187.36.text:
of his mother’s, all the while killing the
guests of his hotel.

2191.14.text:
Fact, in the end, is often not stranger than
fiction.
